title: How to Move Between Tabs in Excel: Windows & Mac

steps.title: Open your project in Excel.
steps.content: Open your project in Excel. You can open your project within Excel by clicking Open from the File tab, or you can right-click on the file in a file browser and click Open With and Excel . You can use this method with both Windows and Mac computers.

steps.title: Press and hold Ctrl (Windows) or ⌥ Option (Mac).
steps.content: Press and hold Ctrl (Windows) or ⌥ Option (Mac). You'll find this key on your keyboard next to the space bar. Keep this key pressed down until otherwise instructed.

steps.title: Press ⇟ PgDn (tab right) or ⇞ PgUp (tab left).
steps.content: Press ⇟ PgDn (tab right) or ⇞ PgUp (tab left). As long as you have the Ctrl or Option key pressed, you can use PgDn and PgUp to cycle through your spreadsheet's tabs. If this doesn't work, or if you have a laptop, try pressing and holding the Fn key along with Ctrl / Option , and then pressing PgDn or PgUp . On a MacBook with no PgDn or PgUp keys, use Option + the right or left arrow key to move between sheets.

steps.title: Release Ctrl (Windows) or ⌥ Option (Mac) when you are done cycling through the tabs.
steps.content: Release Ctrl (Windows) or ⌥ Option (Mac) when you are done cycling through the tabs. Only after you are done navigating through the tabs should you release the Ctrl or Option key. If you continue pressing PgDn or PgUp , you'll most likely end up at the top or bottom of the spreadsheet instead of cycling through tabs.

steps.title: Use other keyboard shortcuts (optional).
steps.content: Use other keyboard shortcuts (optional). Excel has a few other available keyboard shortcuts to use that function a little differently. To move to a different tab without loading unused ones: Press F6 and use the right/left arrow key to select the sheet. Press Enter/Return to open the tab. To quickly navigate to the last tab of a workbook: Hold Ctrl and left-click the small arrow next to the sheet tabs. Then, click the last tab.

steps.title: Open your project in Excel.
steps.content: Open your project in Excel. You can open your project within Excel by clicking Open from the File tab, or you can right-click on the file in a file browser and click Open With and Excel . You can use this method with both Windows and Mac computers.

steps.title: Press F5.
steps.content: Press F5 . You'll see the F numbers above the row of numbers on your keyboard. A "Go To" window will open. You can also press Ctrl + G on Windows to pull up the "Go To" window. You can also go to Home > Find & Select > Go To from the menu. [1] X Trustworthy Source Microsoft Support Technical support and product information from Microsoft. Go to source On some keyboards, you may have to press the Fn key at the same time as F5 .

steps.title: Type the sheet's name that you want to go to.
steps.content: Type the sheet's name that you want to go to. If you did not rename your sheets, the names are generally "Sheet 1/2/3". For example, type Sheet3 to navigate to that sheet.

steps.title: Type an exclamation mark (!
steps.content: Type an exclamation mark (! ). Spaces aren't allowed in the "Go To" feature, so you'll need to use an exclamation mark. For example, type Sheet3! .

steps.title: Type the cell you want to go to.
steps.content: Type the cell you want to go to. If you don't have a specific cell in mind, enter A1 to go to the top of the sheet. For example, enter Sheet3!A1 in the "Go To" window.

steps.title: Press ↵ Enter (Windows) or ⏎ Return (Mac).
steps.content: Press ↵ Enter (Windows) or ⏎ Return (Mac). The dark green outline that indicates which box is selected will go to your entered sheet and cell. You can also click OK in the Go To window.

steps.title: The keyboard shortcut doesn't work.
steps.content: The keyboard shortcut doesn't work. If pressing Ctrl / Option + PgDn/PgUp doesn't work, you may need to press the Fn key first. This is more likely if you're using a laptop. First, press Ctrl / Option + Fn . Then, press PgDn or PgUp to navigate between tabs. If your keyboard doesn’t have a PgDn or PgUp key, you may need to use the right or left arrow keys instead.

steps.title: Is there a faster way to switch tabs?
steps.content: Is there a faster way to switch tabs? If you have a lot of tabs and you want to skip to the last tab, press Ctrl and left click the arrow next to the tab. You can then click the last tab.

steps.title: How do I view two tabs side-by-side?
steps.content: How do I view two tabs side-by-side? To look at two separate tabs together, you can use a built-in feature within Excel. Do the following: Click the View tab at the top. Click New Window in the Window group. Click View Side by Side . Select the tab you want to view in each window. Click Synchronous Scrolling to scroll both tabs at the same time.
